theory_title: Owning a Piece of the Company
theory_content: A **stock** (or share/equity) represents fractional ownership in a publicly traded company. When you buy a stock, you become a shareholder, meaning you own a tiny piece of the company's assets and earnings. This is why stocks are also called 'equities'.

The **Primary Market** is where a company first sells shares to the public through an Initial Public Offering (IPO). The **Secondary Market** is where investors buy and sell existing shares among themselves (this happens on stock exchanges like the NSE or NYSE). Most day-to-day trading occurs in the Secondary Market.

A **dividend** is a payment made by a corporation to its shareholders, usually as a distribution of its profits. Not all companies pay dividends; growth companies often reinvest all profits back into the business.
